original_table_html:
Allocate points according to how well the new product concept rates on the specific dimensions in the following areas:
Consumer Perspectives: Desirability
10 pts. _____ Product category appeal (size, growth potential)
10 pts. _____ Equity transfer (perceived brand fit)
5 pts. _____ Perceived consumer target fit
Company Perspectives: Deliverability
10 pts. _____ Asset leverage (product technology, organizational skills, marketing effectiveness via channels and communications)
10 pts. _____ Profit potential
5 pts. _____ Launch feasibility
Competitive Perspectives: Differentiability
10 pts. _____ Comparative appeal (many advantages, few disadvantages)
10 pts. _____ Competitive response (likelihood, immunity or invulnerability from)
5 pts. _____ Legal/regulatory/institutional barriers
Brand Perspectives: Equity Feedback
10 pts. _____ Strengthens parent brand equity
10 pts. _____ Facilitates additional brand extension opportunities
5 pts. _____ Improves asset base
TOTAL _____ pts
summary_markdown: This framework outlines a point-allocation system for evaluating new product concepts, structured around four key perspectives: Consumer, Company, Competitive, and Brand. Under Consumer Perspectives (Desirability), points assess product category appeal, equity transfer (brand fit), and perceived consumer target fit. Company Perspectives (Deliverability) evaluate asset leverage (technology, skills, marketing), profit potential, and launch feasibility. Competitive Perspectives (Differentiability) consider comparative appeal (advantages vs. disadvantages), competitive response (likelihood and immunity), and legal/regulatory barriers. Finally, Brand Perspectives (Equity Feedback) gauge how the concept strengthens parent brand equity, facilitates extensions, and improves the asset base. A total point score is then calculated, providing a quantitative measure for concept assessment.
